channel.title: Bootstrapped Podcast - Discuss @ Bootstrapped.fm
channel.description: Topics in the 'Bootstrapped Podcast' category The podcast that started it all! We'll post links to each episode here for further discussion.

item.title: #184: When team members quit, with Ed and Steve
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
@freyfogle and @SteveMcLeod discuss what it is like when a core team member quits, how to reduce the chance of it happening, and how to make our businesses resilient enough to handle it.

Watch this episode on YouTube.

1 post - 1 participant

Read full topic
item.source: #184: When team members quit, with Ed and Steve

item.title: #183: Feeling bored and stuck in your business? With Peldi and Ed
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
@peldi concludes his mini-season as host with an open and honest discussion with @freyfogle about a problem every business owner eventually encounters. How do you keep at it when you are feeling bored? Are we stuck in our businesses?

You can also watch this episode on YouTube.

9 posts - 6 participants

Read full topic
item.source: #183: Feeling bored and stuck in your business? With Peldi and Ed

item.title: #182: Responsible product design with Trine Falbe
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
@peldi continues this mini-season as he chats with Trine Falbe, UX strategist & designer, on responsible product design.

Gamification, dark patterns, artificial “roadblocks”, notifications frameworks that exist only to hook you into the product - why bootstrappers shouldn’t mindlessly copy these techniques.

Show notes:

  • Trine’s website
  • Trine’s ethical design scorecard is available for download on https://ethicaldesignhandbook.com/
  • Typeform’s terms of service

You can also watch this episode on YouTube.

Listen, download, and subscribe to the podcast here.

1 post - 1 participant

Read full topic
item.source: #182: Responsible product design with Trine Falbe

item.title: #181: Conducting customer interviews for the reluctant, with Asia Orangio of DemandMaven
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
@peldi continues this mini-season as he chats with Asia Orangio of DemandMaven on how founders can - and should - conduct customer interviews, and how to deal with the discomfort us bootstrappers often feel with this type of work.

Topics includes

  • the discomfort for some of us of talking to customers - but why you should do it anyway
  • how to find the right customers to talk to
  • why delegating customer interviews might actually be a good idea.
  • how to actually conduct a customer interview
  • what not to say, and how not to ask questions

Asia’s company, DemandMaven.

Asia on Twitter.

You can watch this episode on YouTube.

1 post - 1 participant

Read full topic
item.source: #181: Conducting customer interviews for the reluctant, with Asia Orangio of DemandMaven

item.title: #180: Managing the mental ups and downs with Geraldine DeRuiter and Rand Fishkin
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
@peldi continues this mini-season as he chats with married couple Geraldine DeRuiter (author) and Rand Fishkin (software founder) on how their fields differ - and how they are more similar than you’d think.

Peldi, Geraldine, and Rand discuss:

  • How the software industry is less special that we think
  • Dealing with the loneliness and isolation of being a founder or author
  • Managing your own psychology
  • How a supportive partner shares your mental ups and downs
  • The value of having a peer group (aka friends) for mutual support
  • The challenge to ignore the VC hype machine

Geraldine’s blog: The Everywhereist.

Rand’s company SparkToro.

You can also watch this episode on YouTube.

1 post - 1 participant

Read full topic
item.source: #180: Managing the mental ups and downs with Geraldine DeRuiter and Rand Fishkin

item.title: #179: (Peldi) The GDPR 3 years later with Aleth Gueguen of GDPR for SaaS
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Peldi Guilizzoni (@peldi) steps in as host this week, and chats with GDPR expert Aleth Gueguen about how the GDPR is shaping and affecting our SaaS businesses.

Topics include:

  • Is the GDPR being enforced?
  • How has it changed our businesses?
  • How can we shape new businesses to ensure we meet data protection requirements?
  • Does the GDPR give larger businesses an unfair advantage?

You can also watch this episode on YouTube.

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: #179: (Peldi) The GDPR 3 years later with Aleth Gueguen of GDPR for SaaS

item.title: #178: The Hungry Time, with Ed Freyfogle
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Both Ed and Steve are feeling a little bit stressed, perhaps at the beginning of burnout. We discuss why this might be, and what we are doing about it.

This episode is the end of the current season.

A new mini-season starts next with an acting guest host stepping in for the next few weeks while I take a break. In this episode we reveal our who guest host will be.

Who is the guest host? A clue: I interviewed the guest host on a recent episode that is on the Bootstrapped YouTube channel.

7 posts - 6 participants

Read full topic
item.source: #178: The Hungry Time, with Ed Freyfogle

item.title: #177: When life is turned upside down, with Nick Swan of SEOTesting
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Nick Swan was about to launch paid plans for his SaaS when a sudden terrible life event changed everything for Nick and his family.

“The doctor said, ‘You have to go the main hospital now. Drive straight up there. Don’t even pack a bag.’ He didn’t say what it was, but he said it was serious.”

We discuss how this affected his life, his family and his mentality as a bootstrapper.

Nick’s SaaS, SEOTesting

Watch on YouTube.

You can also listen, subscribe, and download here.

3 posts - 3 participants

Read full topic
item.source: #177: When life is turned upside down, with Nick Swan of SEOTesting

item.title: #176: Tips for self-publishing a book, with science fiction writer Aidan Doyle
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Aidan Doyle is a science fiction writer. Amongst his work are two self-published books, including The Writer’s Book of Doubt. I’m planning to produce a book later this year as a marketing endeavour for Feature Upvote. So I chatted with Aidan to get tips on how to do this well.

  • Aidan’s website
  • Aidan on Twitter
  • The Writer’s Book of Doubt

You can also download, listen and subscribe here.

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: #176: Tips for self-publishing a book, with science fiction writer Aidan Doyle

item.title: #175: Riskiness of being a side project’s customer
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Ed and Steve discuss:

  • the return of Microconf Europe as an in-person event
  • working out if a new feature is worth the effort
  • weighing the risk of becoming a customer of someone’s side project

This episode is also on YouTube.

4 posts - 4 participants

item.title: Bootstrapped Podcast on YouTube
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
The Bootstrapped podcast now has a YouTube channel.

When the guests agree, I’m posting the podcast episodes there with full video.

The most recent five episodes are available to watch.

YouTube

Bootstrapped Podcast

If you are running a bootstrapped software company, or thinking of running a bootstrapped software company, this is the podcast for you.

Please like, subscribe, yada yada yada.

Read full topic

item.title: #174: Corey Haines, founder of the Swipe Files community
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
My guest in this episode is Corey Haines, founder of Swipe Files. Swipe Files is a membership site that provides content, community, and courses to help you master marketing.

  • Learn more about Swipe Files.
  • Corey’s podcast: Everything is Marketing.

This episode is also on YouTube.

item.title: #173: Reducing the support workload with Ed Freyfogle
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
@freyfogle is back! We talk about Ed’s systematic attempt to reduce his support workload.

This episode is also on YouTube: https://youtu.be/YnhAH9_OSRg

Listen, subscribe and download here.

item.title: #172: Getting rid of Google Analytics, with Alex Yumashev
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Alex Yumashev (@jitbit), founder of JitBit, returns to the show. We discuss:

  • why Alex ditched Google Analytics from his website
  • how he keeps his work interesting after so many years running the same business
  • why differentiation is often not possible
  • finding freelancers
  • the good and bad of being a bootstrapping entrepreneur

Also mentioned:

  • Plausible Analytics
  • f5bot.com

This episode is also on YouTube.

You can also download, listen and subscribe to this episode here.

6 posts - 6 participants

Read full topic
item.source: #172: Getting rid of Google Analytics, with Alex Yumashev

item.title: #171: Nick Franklin, founder of ChartMogul
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Nick Franklin and I talked about what it is like to go down the venture capital route instead of bootstrapping.

For me this was a glimpse into another way of doing things.

Nick and I discussed:

  • why he used outside investment to create ChartMogul
  • ChartMogul’s focus on creating good content
  • finding a steady stream of interesting things to write about
  • the difficulty of knowing how customers are acquired
  • getting pricing right

Nick on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Nick_Franklin

ChartMogul: https://chartmogul.com/

This episode is also on YouTube.

You can also listen, subscribe, and download here.

1 post - 1 participant

Read full topic
item.source: #171: Nick Franklin, founder of ChartMogul

item.title: #170: “Be so good they can’t ignore you”, with Peldi of Balsamiq
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Peldi Guilizzoni is the founder of low-fidelity wireframing tool Balsamiq.

Peldi and Steve discuss:

  • why Peldi tracks almost nothing except revenue and profits
  • talking to customers instead of using analytics
  • on being “so good they can’t ignore you”
  • how to apply a coder’s approach to marketing
  • how Balsamiq is run like a “cozy restaurant on the web”
  • not getting to code much when running a software company
  • the painful experience of rewriting Balsamiq Wireframes from scratch that took five years (!)
  • choosing technology carefully for your company

This episode is also on YouTube.

You can also listen to this episode here.

6 posts - 5 participants

Read full topic
item.source: #170: “Be so good they can’t ignore you”, with Peldi of Balsamiq

item.title: #169: Email newsletter or no email newsletter? The great debate
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
We argue for and against having a monthly email newsletter for your product. Ed is firmly in the “No way” corner. Steve represents the “You gotta have a newsletter” side. Let the debate begin!

Also mentioned:

  • Do Open - How a simple email newsletter can transform your business (and it can), by David Hieatt

You can also download or listen to this episode here.

5 posts - 5 participants

Read full topic
item.source: #169: Email newsletter or no email newsletter? The great debate

item.title: #168: Twitter for Marketing, and Zombie Customers
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Ed and I cover a lot of ground this week:

  • podcasting nerves
  • geotrivia as marketing
  • a brief foray into geopolitics
  • using Twitter for marketing
  • the frustrating unpredictability of what marketing efforts will bear fruit
  • the pleasure of working from home
  • dealing with zombie customers

The Bootstrapped podcast now has its own Twitter account - follow to receive daily tips for bootstrappers.

You can also listen, download, and subscribe here.

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: #168: Twitter for Marketing, and Zombie Customers

item.title: #167: The blog gets posts once every 13 years
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Ed and Steve talk about the mental stress of having real-time business metrics, how to find a business mentor, and Steve’s attempt to get started with enterprise sales.

And we talk about the blog that posts very infrequently.

You can also listen, download, and subscribe here

6 posts - 3 participants

Read full topic

item.title: #166: Making an Open Source business work with Allan Jardine of DataTables
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Allan Jardine is the creator of DataTables, a popular jQuery plugin. We discuss his challenges and successes as he learned how to make a viable business from creating Open Source software.

We also discuss Allan’s new SaaS product, CloudTables.

You can also listen, download, and subscribe here.

8 posts - 6 participants

Read full topic
item.source: #166: Making an Open Source business work with Allan Jardine of DataTables

item.title: #165: Finding and hiring freelancers
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
In this episode I answer some listener questions about freelancers. I discuss how to find, hire, and communicate with freelancers.

You can also listen and subscribe to be notified of forthcoming episodes here.

item.title: #164: A Saber Feedback update 9 months after acquisition
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Ed grills me on my progress with Saber Feedback, my B2B SaaS, nine months after I acquired it. We talk about SEO, competitors, getting backlinks, finding a niche, and resisting the temptation to write code instead of doing marketing.

15 posts - 6 participants

item.title: #163: Our goals for 2021
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Ed and I discuss what we want to achieve in 2021. Last year, unexpected world events turned our “goals for 2020” upside-down. Having learnt no lesson whatsoever from this, we fearlessly enter 2021 with plans!

We mentioned Ed’s personal blog in this episode.

You can also listen, download, and subscribe to this episode here.

3 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: #163: Our goals for 2021

item.title: #162: Reviewing our 2020 goals
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Steve and Ed look back at the goals they set for 2020 at the beginning of the year. What goals did we hit? What goals eluded us? What did we learn along the way?

You can also listen, download and subscribe here.

item.title: #161: The inglorious launch of my first product
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
This is a talk I recently gave at Barcelona’s ESIC business school. Ostensibly, I spoke on working with intangibles as products. But actually, I told the story of how I started as a bootstrapper – and revealed how clueless I was at the beginning.

So, if you are curious about how I got started creating and selling software products, then you’ll enjoy this episode.

You can also listen to and download this episode.

1 post - 1 participant

Read full topic
item.source: #161: The inglorious launch of my first product
